pageData.text: All organisms require captured and stored energy to fuel the demands for cellular processes that are essential for life. This laboratory activity will guide your investigation of <button class='glossary-text'>cellular respiration</button> using garden peas as an experimental system. A respirometer (a device that measures oxygen consumption) will be constructed and used to observe, measure, and compare the rate of cellular respiration in both germinating and dormant pea seeds. The rate of cellular respiration of the pea seeds will be compared with the respiration rate of a blank control.

pageData.title: Time Requirements
pageData.desc:
Preparation (First Day) - 5 minutes 
Preparation (Second Day) - 15 minutes 
Activity 1: Experimental System SetUp for Cellular Respiration - 60 minutes 
Activity 2: Conducting the Cellular Respiration Experiment - 40 minutes
pageData.altText:
Preparation (First Day) - 5 minutes 
Preparation (Second Day) - 15 minutes
Activity 1: Experimental System Set-Up for Cellular Respiration - 60 minutes 
Activity 2: Conducting the Cellular Respiration Experiment - 40 minutes

text: Disposable aluminum baking pan, two 9 ✕ 13” pans, or a single larger roasting pan (preferred)
3 Nickels
Timer or stopwatch
Food coloring
Plastic cup, 10 oz (for germinating seeds)
Paper towels
Resealable bag, sandwich size
Scissors
Water, nonchlorinated (bottled spring water or distilled water)

pageData.subTitle: Overview Video: Cellular Respiration in Germinating Peas

text: Describe the three stages of <button class='glossary-text'>cellular respiration</button>.
Explain the roles oxygen and carbon dioxide play in cellular respiration.
Prepare and execute an experiment to observe and measure the rate of cellular respiration in both germinating and dormant pea seeds.
Analyze data collected using a simple respirometer.

pageData.text: One of the consequences of mankind’s agricultural and industrial activities is the run-off of pollutants into estuaries and coastal water bodies. This run-off contains elements that are vital nutrients for photosynthetic algae, causing them to grow at an exponential rate and create algal blooms so large they can sometimes be seen from space. In 2018, an algal bloom called the great Atlantic sargassum belt became the largest algal bloom ever recorded. It spanned 5,000 miles, from the coast of West Africa to the Gulf of Mexico. Although sargassum blooms serve as an important refuge for hundreds of marine species, super-sized blooms harm coastal biodiversity, fisheries, the tourism industry, and human health.

As algal blooms are broken down by marine microbes via <button class='glossary-text'>cellular respiration</button>, oxygen is depleted from the water. When massive blooms decompose, the oxygen levels drop significantly, leaving other organisms – and ultimately entire ecosystems – without enough oxygen to survive. This degradation of aquatic ecosystems by excessive nutrient output is called eutrophication.

Image attribution: This image by Fabio Achilli is licensed under CC BY 2.0.
https://www.flickr.com/photos/travelourplanet/15159276755

pageData.desc: A man standing on the beach surrounded by brown algae
pageData.altText: A man standing on the beach surrounded by brown algae

pageData.text: Plants and some algae are the only organisms that can harness the energy of the sun in a process called <button class='glossary-text'>photosynthesis</button>, which synthesizes sugars and other molecules that support cellular metabolism. The sugars produced during photosynthesis are transported throughout the plant and stored in roots and seeds. How do plants acquire energy when they germinate underground, out of the reach of sunlight? The answer: they metabolize the stored sugars, much like humans do, through the process of <button class='glossary-text'>cellular respiration</button>.

All cells need energy. Energy is contained in the chemical bonds of organic compounds such as carbohydrates, proteins, and fats. Simple carbohydrates, such as sugars, are a primary source of chemical energy. When the chemical bonds of a sugar molecule are broken down (metabolized) by specific enzymes in a series of small steps, the energy stored in those bonds is used to synthesize a molecule called <button class='glossary-text'>adenosine triphosphate</button> (ATP).

ATP is the main form of energy used by cells. The energy is stored in the chemical bonds of its three-phosphate tail. When one of these phosphate bonds is broken and the phosphate is removed from the ATP molecule to produce <button class='glossary-text'>adenosine diphosphate</button> (ADP), it releases a large amount of energy that can be harnessed to power almost all metabolic and cellular processes (Figure 1). Within each cell there is constant cycling between ATP and ADP for respiration, fermentation, and other metabolic processes.

pageData.desc: Figure 1: One phosphate bond breaking off of the ATP molecule to produce ADP; showing, in turn, a large amount of energy being released for harnessing power for almost all metabolic and cellular processes.
pageData.altText: Figure 1: One phosphate bond breaking off of the ATP molecule to produce ADP; showing, in turn, a large amount of energy being released for harnessing power for almost all metabolic and cellular processes.

pageData.text: This investigation focuses on aerobic <button class='glossary-text'>cellular respiration</button>. The chemical reactions that occur during aerobic cellular respiration are grouped into four processes called <button class='glossary-text'>glycolysis</button>, acetylcoenzyme A (<button class='glossary-text'>acetyl-CoA</button>) synthesis, <button class='glossary-text'>Krebs cycle</button> (citric acid cycle), and <button class='glossary-text'>electron-transport chain</button>. The complete metabolism of one sugar molecule during cellular respiration is summarized by the following equation:
C6H12O6 + 6O2   6CO2 + 6H2O + 36 ATP
pageData.altText: Equation for cellular respiration reaction used in this experiment

pageData.subTitle: Glycolysis
pageData.text: Glycolysis is a series of 10 reactions that converts a 6-carbon glucose molecule into  two 3-carbon molecules called <button class='glossary-text'>pyruvate</button>. Glycolysis occurs in the cell cytoplasm. Four ATP molecules and two NADH molecules are produced during glycolysis. Two ATP molecules are required to start the series of reactions; therefore, there is a net gain of two ATP  molecules (see Table 1).

If oxygen is present, cells may undergo aerobic cellular respiration to produce more energy by metabolizing the derivatives of glucose. All higher organisms and many microorganisms have the necessary enzymes to perform aerobic cellular respiration.

pageData.subTitle: Acetyl-Coenzyme A Synthesis and Krebs Cycle
pageData.text: In the presence of oxygen, the <button class='glossary-text'>pyruvate</button> synthesized during <button class='glossary-text'>glycolysis</button> enters mitochondria and is initially converted into a molecule called <button class='glossary-text'>acetyl-CoA</button>. One molecule of carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>) and one molecule of NADH are produced during the conversion of pyruvate to acetyl-CoA. The acetyl-CoA is then metabolized through a series of six reactions called the <button class='glossary-text'>Krebs cycle</button>, or the citric acid cycle. Each molecule of acetyl-CoA is metabolized to produce two molecules of CO<sub>2</sub> and some of the released energy is used to synthesize ATP. Some of the released energy is in the form of electrons, which are transferred to the electron-carrier molecules NAD<sup>+</sup> and FAD to yield the reduced forms NADH and FADH<sub>2</sub> . The electrons held by these electron carriers represent energy that can be used to synthesize ATP in the <button class='glossary-text'>electron-transport chain</button>.The NADH and FADH<sub>2</sub> molecules are called electron carriers because they transport electrons and associated hydrogen atoms to a series of membrane-embedded proteins called the electron-transport chain. Here, the hydrogens and electrons are stripped from the electron carriers, so NADH is oxidized to NAD<sup>+</sup> and FADH<sub>2</sub> is oxidized to FADH. These specialized  electron-carrier molecules constantly cycle between reduced and oxidized forms within  the cell.

When these electrons are removed from NADH and FADH<sub>2</sub> and transferred from one protein to the next protein, they release energy that is used to shuttle hydrogen ions into the intermembrane space of the mitochondria. As the ions accumulate, they form an ionic gradient across the membrane. This ionic gradient creates an electrochemical imbalance across the membrane that is harnessed to produce ATP. In this process, hydrogen ions are allowed to pass through a membrane channel formed by a protein called <button class='glossary-text'>ATP synthase</button>. ATP synthase functions somewhat like a windmill. The flow of hydrogen ions through the membrane channel causes one part of the ATP synthase complex to spin, which drives the production of ATP. In this reaction, ATP synthase catalyzes the phosphorylation of ADP by adding another phosphate to produce ATP (Figure 2). In eukaryotic cells, one electron donated from each NADH yields three  ATP molecules, and one electron donated  from each FADH<sub>2</sub> yields two ATP molecules. The <button class='glossary-text'>electron-transport chain</button> produces 16 ATP molecules for each <button class='glossary-text'>pyruvate</button> molecule. Each glucose molecule produces two pyruvate  molecules. Therefore, aerobic <button class='glossary-text'>cellular respiration</button> of each glucose molecule produces approximately 32 ATP molecules (see <button class='resource-text'>Table 1</button>).

pageData.desc: Figure 2: An illustration of ATP synthesis via the electron transport chain
pageData.altText: Figure 2: An illustration of ATP synthesis via the electron transport chain

pageData.question: All cells need energy. This energy is contained in which of the following?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Energy is contained in the chemical bonds of organic compounds such as carbohydrates, proteins, and fats.

pageData.question: ATP is the main energy-rich molecule used by cells. ATP’s energy is stored in which of the following?

options.text: the chemical bonds between the phosphate groups of the molecule
the enzyme that converts ATP to ADP

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The energy is stored in the chemical bonds between ATP’s three phosphate groups.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Plants and some algae are the only organisms that can harness the energy of the sun in a process called photosynthesis, which synthesizes sugars and other molecules that support cellular metabolism. The sugars produced during photosynthesis are transported throughout the plant and stored in roots and seeds. When seeds germinate underground, they metabolize the stored sugars, much like humans do, through the process of cellular respiration. All cells need energy. Simple carbohydrates, such as sugars, are a primary source of chemical energy. When the chemical bonds of a sugar molecule are broken down (metabolized) by specific enzymes in a series of small steps, the energy stored in those bonds is used to synthesize a molecule called adenosine triphosphate (ATP). When one of the phosphate bonds is broken and the phosphate is removed from the ATP molecule to produce adenosine diphosphate (ADP), it releases a large amount of energy that can be harnessed to power almost all metabolic and cellular processes.

img.alt: Figure 1: The phospholipid bilayer structure of a cell membrane. The hydrophobic tails associate with one another to form the interior of the membrane. The hydrophilic heads form the boundary between the extracellular and intracellular environments.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Plants and some algae are the only organisms that can harness the energy of the sun in a process called photosynthesis, which synthesizes sugars and other molecules that support cellular metabolism. The sugars produced during photosynthesis are transported throughout the plant and stored in roots and seeds. When seeds germinate underground, they metabolize the stored sugars, much like humans do, through the process of cellular respiration. All cells need energy. Simple carbohydrates, such as sugars, are a primary source of chemical energy. When the chemical bonds of a sugar molecule are broken down (metabolized) by specific enzymes in a series of small steps, the energy stored in those bonds is used to synthesize a molecule called adenosine triphosphate (ATP). When one of the phosphate bonds is broken and the phosphate is removed from the ATP molecule to produce adenosine diphosphate (ADP), it releases a large amount of energy that can be harnessed to power almost all metabolic and cellular processes.

img.alt: Figure 1: The phospholipid bilayer structure of a cell membrane. The hydrophobic tails associate with one another to form the interior of the membrane. The hydrophilic heads form the boundary between the extracellular and intracellular environments.

pageData.text: Oxygen enters the equations during the final step of the <button class='glossary-text'>electron-transport chain</button>. When the electrons reach the last protein, they are transferred, along with hydrogen atoms, to oxygen, resulting in the formation of water (H<sub>2</sub>O). For this reason, oxygen (O<sub>2</sub>) is called the terminal electron carrier. The transfer of electrons to oxygen at the end of the transport chain enables more electrons to enter the start of the chain. If no oxygen is available, no more electrons can be transferred from NADH and FADH<sub>2</sub> to enter the start of the transport chain. In the absence of oxygen, the electron-transport chain and <button class='glossary-text'>Krebs cycle</button> cease to function, and the cell becomes starved of ATP and other organic compounds.

pageData.subTitle: Using a Respirometer
pageData.text: This investigation uses a respirometer to measure the respiration rate of germinating and dormant pea seeds (and uses beads as a blank control sample). The respirometer is composed of a vial containing the peas and a volume of air; the mouth of the vial is sealed with a one-hole rubber stopper with a pipet inserted into the hole. To perform the experiment, the entire respirometer is completely submerged in water. If the peas respire, they will use oxygen (O<sub>2</sub>) and release carbon dioxide (CO<sub>2</sub>). Because 1 mole of carbon dioxide is released for each mole of oxygen consumed, there is no change in the volume of gas in the respirometer.

However, we can experimentally alter this equilibrium by placing a cotton ball that has been saturated with a solution of potassium hydroxide (KOH) into the bottom of the vial. Potassium hydroxide reacts with carbon dioxide to form potassium carbonate (K<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub>), which is a solid. The following reaction occurs:
CO2 + 2KOH   K2CO3 + H2O
Avogadro’s Law: At constant temperature and pressure, 1 mole of any gas has the same volume as 1 mole of any other gas.

Inside the respirometer, solid K<sub>2</sub>CO<sub>3</sub> is not observed because it dissolves within the saturated cotton ball as rapidly as it is formed. Therefore, in this experimental setup, <button class='glossary-text'>cellular respiration</button> consumes oxygen and produces carbon dioxide, which is removed by its reaction with potassium hydroxide, leading to a reduction in the volume of gas inside the submerged respirometer. As the volume of gas inside the vial decreases, water moves from the bath into the submerged pipet. The gas volume decrease is measured from the scale printed on the pipet and can be used to calculate the rate of  respiration.

pageData.question: What is the purpose of adding potassium hydroxide (KOH) to the respirometers in this investigation?

options.text: to sequester carbon dioxide gas as solid potassium carbonate
to keep the respirometer at an alkaline pH
to remove humidity from the respirometer
to activate the dormant pea seeds
to add humidity to the respirometer

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: In this experimental setup, cellular respiration consumes oxygen and produces carbon dioxide, which is removed by its reaction with potassium hydroxide, leading to a reduction in the volume of gas inside the submerged respirometer.

pageData.question: If cellular respiration takes place inside a respirometer, the volume of gas inside the vial decreases. A change in the amount of which of the following molecules is being measured?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: As oxygen gas is consumed by the process of cellular respiration, the overall volume of gas inside the vial decreases.

pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow for this investigation. Before starting any activities, germinate some pea seeds and prepare a water bath. In Activity 1, you will assemble 3 respirometers, test their seals, and then add peas and/or beads to each respirometer. In Activity 2, you will equilibrate the respirometers in a water bath. If the respirometers are leaking, you will remove the respirometer’s contents, then repeat testing the seal, adding the contents back in, and equilibrating the respirometer. Otherwise, you will submerge the respirometers in the water bath and equilibrate them there. Then, measure the respirometers’ volumes in 5-minute intervals for 20 minutes. Finally, you will determine the change in volume and whether cellular respiration took place in each respirometer.
pageData.desc: A map of the procedural workflow for this investigation. Before starting any activities, germinate some pea seeds and prepare a water bath. In Activity 1, you will assemble 3 respirometers, test their seals, and then add peas and/or beads to each respirometer. In Activity 2, you will equilibrate the respirometers in a water bath. If the respirometers are leaking, you will remove the respirometer’s contents, then repeat testing the seal, adding the contents back in, and equilibrating the respirometer. Otherwise, you will submerge the respirometers in the water bath and equilibrate them there. Then, measure the respirometers’ volumes in 5-minute intervals for 20 minutes. Finally, you will determine the change in volume and whether cellular respiration took place in each respirometer.

pageData.text: Reorder Information: Replacement supplies for the Cellular Respiration in Germinating Peas investigation (item number 580118) can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company.Call: 866-332-4478 to order.
Wear your safety goggles, gloves, and apron at all times while conducting this investigation.

pageData.desc: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol
pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.text: Read all the instructions for the laboratory activities before beginning. Follow the instructions closely, and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate personal protective equipment (PPE).

pageData.altText: corrosion symbol
pageData.text: Potassium Hydroxide is a corrosive material that causes severe skin burns and eye damage. It is harmful to aquatic life. Use this material near a source of running water that can be used as a safety eye wash or safety shower if any corrosive material comes in contact with skin or eyes.

Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing these activities. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing each activity. Clean the work area with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span className=bodyParaLineBreak>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Plants conduct which of the following metabolic processes?
Which process results in the highest net production of ATP?

Leah is conducting the cellular respiration experiment in this investigation. She forgets to add potassium hydroxide (KOH) to the respirometers, which are otherwise assembled correctly. Which of the following outcomes would you most likely expect to observe from Leah’s experiment?

options.text: None of the respirometers show volume changes.
The control respirometer shows a decrease in volume.
The germinated-pea respirometer shows an increase in volume.
The dormant-pea respirometer shows an increase in volume.
The pea-filled respirometers start to decompose.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following describes the correct starting material(s) for the electron-transport chain?
Which of the following occurs entirely in the cytoplasm of a eukaryotic cell (such as a plant cell)?
Which of the following steps of cellular respiration requires oxygen (O<sub>2</sub>)?
Which of the following safety hazards is associated with potassium hydroxide (KOH)?

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: Congratulations!!! You passed the Pre-lab Assessment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Result
pageData.text: You have not passed the pre-lab assessment. You must score 100% to unlock the rest of the investigation. Please review the pre-lab sections again before re-attempting this assessment. You have unlimited attempts to pass this assessment. Click the Review Pre-Lab button to be returned to the start of the pre-lab section.
Place 50 garden pea seeds (dormant seeds) into a small plastic cup.

typeBefore.title: Two days before conducting Activity 1 (03 steps)

pageData.text: Cover the peas with nonchlorinated water to a depth of at least three times their height in the cup. This depth allows for expansion of the seeds as they swell.
Allow the seeds to soak overnight at room temperature.

Common tap water contains chlorine for sanitation, which may negatively affect seed germination. For best results, use bottled spring water, distilled water, filtered water (if it removes the chlorine), or add an aquarium chlorine removal agent to tap water.

Pour off the remaining water in the cup of hydrated pea seeds, and then place the seeds on a paper towel saturated with nonchlorinated water. Each seed should be in direct contact with the wet paper towel. Arrange the seeds on one-half of the area of the paper towel.

typeBefore.title: One day before conducting Activity 1 (04 steps)

pageData.text: Fold the other half of the paper towel over the seeds, and then place into a resealable bag.
Close the bag and store the seeds in a dark place overnight.

Prepare a water bath: If using two 9 ✕ 13” pans, fill them both to a depth of approximately 1½” of tap water. If using one larger roasting pan (preferred), fill it to a depth of approximately 1½” of tap water. Allow the water to stand overnight so that it comes to room temperature.
In Activity 1, you will assemble and calibrate three respirometers containing dormant peas, germinated peas, and/or plastic beads.

pages.pageTitle: Experimental System SetUp for Cellular Respiration
pages.title: Experimental System SetUp for Cellular Respiration

pageData.text: Place one nickel in the bottom of each glass vial.

typeBefore.text:
The following materials are needed:
  • 3 Flat-bottom glass vials
  • 3 Nickels
  • Scissors
  • 2 Parafilm® squares, 2 ✕ 2”
  • 3 Rubber stoppers with holes
  • 3 Serological pipets, 1 mL

typeBefore.desc: How to Set Up and Interpret Respirometers

pageData.text: Take two squares of Parafilm<sup>®</sup> (2 ✕ 2”). Cut each square in half to make two 1 ✕ 2” strips. Use one strip for each of the three respirometers.
To assemble the top of the respirometers, gather one rubber stopper, one 1-mL serological pipet, and one strip of Parafilm.<sup>®</sup>

pageData.desc: Figure 3: Experimental setup for constructing a respirometer. A pipet tip wrapped in Parafilm® is connected into a stopper. The stopper is inserted into a glass vial to make a respirometer.
pageData.altText: Figure 3: Experimental setup for constructing a respirometer. A pipet tip wrapped in Parafilm® is connected into a stopper. The stopper is inserted into a glass vial to make a respirometer.

pageData.text: Remove the waxed paper from a strip of Parafilm<sup>®</sup>, and tightly wrap the strip around one of the serological pipets, approximately 1<sup>1/2</sup>” from the blunt end.
Hold the pipet at the Parafilm<sup>®</sup>, and carefully insert the blunt end of the pipet through the hole in the rubber stopper. This will form an airtight seal (Figure 3).
Hold the pipet as close to the stopper (at the Parafilm<sup>®</sup>) as possible and push carefully.

Take out the water bath that was filled the previous day. The water in the bath will buffer the respirometers against temperature changes and ensure a closed system inside the respirometers during the experiment.

typeBefore.title:
B
  Creating a Water Bath (02 steps)

pageData.text: Test whether the seal between each stopper and pipet is airtight. After setting up the rubber stoppers and pipets, plug the top of each vial with one of the stoppers and completely submerge the respirometer in the water bath for 20–30 seconds. Check for leakage. If the contact between the stopper and the pipet or the stopper and the vial is leaking, water will begin to enter the vial. Simply tighten the stopper and/or the pipet to correct this.  It is better to detect and repair any leaking respirometers at this point before the  experiment has begun to avoid having to repeat the experiment later.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Place a thermometer in the water bath. Check the water temperature two or three times before starting the experiment to verify that the temperature is stable.
Add 25 mL of nonchlorinated water to the 100-mL graduated cylinder.

typeBefore.title:
C
  Setting Up the Peas and Beads (13 steps)

pageData.text: Slowly drop 25 germinating peas into the graduated cylinder.
Observe the final volume (VF) after adding the peas to the graduated cylinder. Record this value in Data Table 1 for germinating peas.

Determine the volume of water that has been displaced by subtracting the initial volume of water
(Vi = 25 mL) from the final volume (VF) after adding 25 germinating peas. The difference in volume is equivalent to the volume of germinating peas. Record the volume of the germinating peas in Data Table 1.
Remove the germinating peas, and place them on a paper towel saturated with nonchlorinated water.
Refill the graduated cylinder with 25 mL of nonchlorinated water.
Slowly drop 25 dry, dormant peas into the graduated cylinder.

Gradually add beads to the graduated cylinder containing dormant peas so that the final volume equals the final volume measured previously for the germinating peas. Adding beads to the graduated cylinder with the smaller, dormant seeds ensures that the respirometers contain equivalent volumes at the start of the experiment.
Tap the graduated cylinder to displace any air bubbles trapped between the pea seeds and the beads during this process.
Remove the dormant peas and beads, and place them on a dry paper towel (keep them separate from the sample of germinating peas).
Record the volume of the dormant peas and beads in Data Table 1. The volume should be the same as that entered for the germinating peas.
Refill the graduated cylinder with 25 mL of water.

Gradually add beads so that the final volume equals the final volumes of the germinating peas and the dormant peas plus beads. All three groups should have equivalent volumes at the start of the experiment.
Remove these beads and place them on a dry paper towel (keep them separate from the sample of dormant peas plus beads).

Caution: It is essential to wear personal protective equipment for all subsequent steps of the activity. First, put on the apron, then the protective gloves, and then the safety goggles. Do not proceed to the next step without wearing this equipment.
Place an absorbent cotton ball on top of the nickel in the bottom of each respirometer vial.

typeBefore.text: Caution: Avoid eye and skin contact with the potassium hydroxide (KOH) solution.

pageData.text: Use a plastic graduated pipet to saturate the cotton with 2.0 mL of 15% potassium hydroxide (KOH) solution. Carefully expel the solution from the pipet to avoid getting KOH on the sides of the glass vials. If KOH does end up on the sides of a vial, dry the vial with a paper towel and dispose of the paper towel in the trash. It is important that the amount of cotton and KOH solution added to the vials are the same for all three respirometers.

typeBefore.desc: See how to use a calibrated pipet

pageData.text: Place a small wad of dry, nonabsorbent cotton on top of the KOH-soaked absorbent cotton. This will prevent the peas from being in contact with the KOH solution, which would damage the peas and could affect the results.
Place the 25 germinating peas into the one of the vials.
Place the 25 dormant peas and beads into another vial.
Place the equivalent volume of beads into the third vial.
Insert a stopper with pipet into each of the three respirometer vials. The stopper must fit tightly. If any of the respirometers leak during the experiment, you must start the experiment over.

Carefully lay the three assembled respirometers on a table or other flat surface without disturbing the moistened cotton ball and seeds, and position the tip of the respirometer pipet over a paper towel. Add some food coloring to the tip of the pipet by hanging a drop of food coloring from a food coloring bottle, so that the drop just touches the tip of the pipet, and allow capillary action to pull the drop into the pipet. The food coloring in the pipet will help you observe volume changes in the pipet during the experiment (Figure 4).

pageData.desc: Figure 4: Food coloring being pulled up into a glass pipet due to capillary action
pageData.altText: Figure 4: Food coloring being pulled up into a glass pipet due to capillary action

pageData.text: In this activity, you will use the respirometers assembled in Activity 1 to measure the rate of <button class='glossary-text'>cellular respiration</button> in germinated peas versus dormant peas.

pages.title:
A
  Conducting the Cellular Respiration Experiment (step 7)
pages.pageTitle:
A
  Conducting the Cellular Respiration Experiment (step 7)

pageData.text: Place the three respirometers into the water bath in an upright position with the pipet tips resting on the lip of the water bath (Figure 5).

pageData.desc: Figure 5: Three respirometers sitting upright in a water bath with the pipet tips resting on the lip of the water bath.
pageData.altText: Figure 5: Three respirometers sitting upright in a water bath with the pipet tips resting on the lip of the water bath.

pageData.text: If using two 9 x 13” pans, place two respirometers in one bath and one in the other. To submerge the respirometers, angle each so that it lays diagonally in the pan with all respirometers fully submerged.

Allow the respirometers to equilibrate for 5 minutes. This will allow the internal temperature of each vial and its contents to reach thermal equilibrium with the water in the bath and with each other. If any of the respirometers begin to fill with water, there is a leak and you must start the experiment over.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: After the equilibration period, submerge all the respirometers (including the pipet tips) in the water bath. Position the respirometers so that the scale can be read on each of the pipets. Do not put anything into or take anything out of the water bath until all the necessary measurements have been recorded.
Allow the respirometers to equilibrate for another 5 minutes or until the the dye on the respirometer containing the germinated peas has passed the zero mark on the pipet, whichever is later.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: After these equilibrium periods, observe the initial volume reading on the pipet scale of each respirometer to the nearest 0.01 mL. Record this information in Data Table 2 for “Time 0.” Observe and record the temperature of the water bath.

If the dye has not moved into the pipet sufficiently far enough to be able to record the initial volume, mark the location of the dye on the edge of the dye farthest from the tip. In subsequent steps, estimate the change in volume.

Take observations of the volume on the scale of each respirometer every 5 minutes for 20 minutes, and record this information in Data Table 2. Record the temperature of the water bath for each of the 5-minute intervals.
pageData.altText: stopwatch symbol

pageData.text: Use the collected data to perform the calculations necessary to complete Data Table 2.
Caution: Keep all personal protective equipment on during the cleanup.

text: Take the stoppers out of the respirometers, and pour the water from the vials down a sink drain. Hold the seeds and/or beads with a gloved hand to keep them from falling into the drain.
Rinse gloved hand, seeds, and beads with water.
Empty the water from the water bath into the sink, and rinse the sink.
Discard the peas and beads in the trash.
Remove the nonabsorbent cotton, KOH-soaked cotton, and nickel from the vial using a gloved hand. Rinse these items well with water. Dispose of the cotton in the trash.
Remove the serological pipets from each stopper by holding the pipet and Parafilm® close to the stopper and carefully pulling the pipet out of the stopper.

Wrap the vials in newspaper, paper bags, or other sturdy paper. Tape the paper securely shut, and place it in the trash. Wrapping the glass vials in paper will prevent anyone who handles the trash from cutting themselves should the glass break.
Dispose of gloves, pipets, stoppers, and any remaining disposables in the trash. Wash hands thoroughly.

pageData.text: You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.
pageData.confirmationMessage: Are you sure you want to submit your work? You will not be able to edit the lab notebook after submitting your work.

pageData.altText: completion

pageData.title: Data Table 1. Determination of Volume of Germinating Peas

pageData.text: Note: The values in each column for all three samples (germinating peas, dormant peas + beads, and beads only) will be identical. The experiment is designed to have equivalent volumes in each of the three respirometers, which is determined by (and equal to) the volume of the germinating peas.

pageData.title: Data Table 2. Measurement of Volume Changes During Respiration of Peas at Room Temperature

pageData.text: The volume in the pipet is affected by ambient air pressure. In order to correct for any pressure changes that occur during the experiment, the change in volume in Respirometer 3 (the control) is subtracted from the change in volume in Respirometers 1 and 2.
Change in volume = (Volume at time 0) – (Volume at time of current reading)
Corrected change in volume = (Change in volume of respirometer) – (Change in volume of Respirometer 3)

text: Which of the respirometers serves as control? Explain your answer.
Assuming your experimental control measures worked, identify what variable(s) changed to bring about the observed change in volume (corrected change in volume for Respirometers 1 and 2)?

Summarize your results from the data tables. Compare the results from the respirometers containing germinating and dormant peas. Speculate about the cause(s) of any difference between the two pea samples. Explain your reasoning.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: The phospholipid bilayer structure of a cell membrane. The hydrophobic tails associate with one another to form the interior of the membrane. The hydrophilic heads form the boundary between the extracellular and intracellular environments.
pageData.content: Figure 1. Synthesis and hydrolysis of ATP

pageData.altText: Figure 2: An illustration of ATP synthesis via the electron transport chain
pageData.content: Figure 2. Electron transport chain of aerobic cellular respiration

pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow for this investigation. Before starting any activities, germinate some pea seeds and prepare a water bath. In Activity 1, you will assemble 3 respirometers, test their seals, and then add peas and/or beads to each respirometer. In Activity 2, you will equilibrate the respirometers in a water bath. If the respirometers are leaking, you will remove the respirometer’s contents, then repeat testing the seal, adding the contents back in, and equilibrating the respirometer. Otherwise, you will submerge the respirometers in the water bath and equilibrate them there. Then, measure the respirometers’ volumes in 5-minute intervals for 20 minutes. Finally, you will determine the change in volume and whether cellular respiration took place in each respirometer.

pageData.content: How to Set Up and Interpret Respirometers

data.title: Acetyl-CoA
data.content: A coenzyme that participates in protein, carbohydrate, and lipid metabolism

data.title: Adenosine diphosphate
data.content: An intermediate between ATP and AMP; it can be reversibly converted to ATP and releases a large amount of energy that can be harnessed to power almost all metabolic and cellular processes; abbreviated ADP

data.title: Adenosine triphosphate
data.content: The main energy currency of the cell; abbreviated ATP

data.title: ATP synthase
data.content: The enzyme that catalyzes the formation of ATP

data.title: Cellular respiration
data.content: A series of metabolic reactions that convert chemical energy from nutrients into adenosine triphosphate (ATP) and waste products

data.title: Electron-transport chain
data.content: A series of membrane-embedded proteins that take electrons from electron carriers and transfer them from one protein to the next

data.title: Glycolysis
data.content: A series of 10 reactions that converts a 6-carbon glucose molecule into two 3-carbon molecules (pyruvate)

data.title: Krebs cycle
data.content: The process that metabolizes acetyl-CoA in the mitochondria to produce electron carriers for the electron-transport chain; it also produces some ATP, and carbon dioxide and water as waste products; also called the citric acid cycle

data.title: Photosynthesis
data.content: The process of using light energy to power a chemical reaction that yields energy, which can be stored as food
